images.caption: Figure 1:Study design.(a)Three doctors drafted ten medical scenarios, iteratively revising them until they reached unanimous agreement about the best disposition on a five-point scale from self-care to ambulance.(b)Four additional doctors read the scenarios and provided differential diagnoses, which were combined to form gold standard lists of relevant conditions.(c)We recruited 1,298 participants and randomly assigned them to one of four experimental conditions. Each participant was randomly allocated one of ten medical scenarios. The treatment groups conversed with an LLM to help assess the scenarios. The control group was permitted to use any method, with most participants using internet search or their own knowledge.(d)Participants then chose a disposition and identified medical conditions which motivated their choice. Participants completed two scenarios, until a total of 600 examples were collected for each experimental condition. We evaluated each participant’s responses using the gold standard answers.

Figure 2:Performance of LLMs alone and with users.(a) The performance on the LLMs when directly prompted to complete each task alone. (Top) The proportion of LLM responses that identified relevant conditions. (Bottom) The proportion of LLM responses correctly identifying the best disposition. (b) The performance of participants across the four experimental conditions. (Top) The proportion of participant responses that identified relevant conditions. (Bottom) The proportion of participant responses correctly identifying the best disposition. The control group was significantly better than those using LLMs at identifying relevant conditions. Differences in disposition accuracy were not statistically significant. All error bars show 95% confidence intervals for proportions. Using LLMs worsened or did not improve participant performance on these tasks relative to using traditional resources, and the models consistently performed better without user interaction.

Figure 3:Identification of relevant conditions in interaction.The proportion of responses where at least one condition from the gold-standard list (Extended DataTab.14) is mentioned during the interaction between the participants and LLMs. Error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals. Markers indicate means for each scenario.

Figure 4:Model Baselines.aThe accuracy of each model in responding to questions from MedQA relevant to each scenario, as compared with the performance of the human participants using the same model in the main experiment. The human passing standard for MedQA is 60%, which the LLMs mostly achieve. Scores on question-answering are higher than the corresponding scores in user interactions in 26/30 cases for the dispositions and all 30 cases for relevant conditions.bThe accuracy of simulated users in identifying the best disposition and relevant conditions as compared to human users in the main experiment. Dashed lines show linear regressions with shaded 95% confidence intervals.

Figure 5:Post-survey.(Upper Left) Self-reported confidence in urgency assessments, conditioned on the subsequent accuracy of the assessment. Confidence tends to be higher when responses are correct (t-test,p<0.001𝑝0.001p<0.001italic_p < 0.001). In aggregate, mean confidence is higher for the Control group than the Command R+ group (t-test,p=0.002𝑝0.002p=0.002italic_p = 0.002), but similar to Llama 3 80B (p=0.129𝑝0.129p=0.129italic_p = 0.129) and GPT-4o (p=0.754𝑝0.754p=0.754italic_p = 0.754). (Upper Right) Participants ratings as to whether they would recommend LLMs to friends or family for medical purposes or general use. Participants in the GPT-4o group were more likely than those in the Control group to recommend using LLMs for medical purposes (t-test,p<0.001𝑝0.001p<0.001italic_p < 0.001) or general use (p<0.001𝑝0.001p<0.001italic_p < 0.001). The other groups showed no significant difference to the control (Llama 3,p=0.662𝑝0.662p=0.662italic_p = 0.662,p=0.527𝑝0.527p=0.527italic_p = 0.527; Command R+,p=0.333𝑝0.333p=0.333italic_p = 0.333,p=0.370𝑝0.370p=0.370italic_p = 0.370). Mean ratings and 95% confidence intervals are shown. (Lower) Participants reported the degree to which they relied on each potential source of information. Cells show mean next step accuracy and condition identification accuracy for users reporting each degree of influence by source, with counts per cell in parenthesis.

Figure 6:Incorrect acuity estimates by treatment group.(a.)The proportion of participants overestimating the acuity of the condition for each condition.(b.)The proportion of participants correctly estimating the acuity of the condition for each condition.(c.)The proportion of participants underestimating the acuity of the condition for each condition. Error bars are 95% confidence intervals adjusted with Bonferroni corrections for 30 comparisons.

Figure 7:Matching Threshold ROC Curve.The rates of true and false positives for fuzzy matching thresholds which tolerate between 0-100% character difference between the participant responses and gold-standard answers. The red ‘x’ indicates 80% match, the threshold that we selected.
